questions.question: A $2 \text{ kg}$ block is at rest on a frictionless surface. A horizontal force of $10 \text{ N}$ pushes it for $5 \text{ m}$. What is its final kinetic energy?
questions.explanation: $W = Fd = 10 \times 5 = 50$ J. By work-energy theorem, $KE_f = W = 50$ J.

questions.question: A $2 \text{ kg}$ block is at rest on a frictionless surface. A horizontal force of $10 \text{ N}$ pushes it for $5 \text{ m}$. What is its final speed?
A $1 \text{ kg}$ object is moving at $10 \text{ m/s}$. How much net work is required to stop it?
How much net work is required to accelerate a $1000 \text{ kg}$ car from $10 \text{ m/s}$ to $20 \text{ m/s}$?
A $5 \text{ kg}$ object experiences $100 \text{ J}$ of net work. If it started with a speed of $2 \text{ m/s}$, what is its final kinetic energy?
A $10 \text{ kg}$ crate slides on a rough floor. Its kinetic energy drops from $200 \text{ J}$ to $50 \text{ J}$ over a distance of $3 \text{ m}$. What was the average friction force?
A projectile is launched with $v_x = 3 \text{ m/s}$ and $v_y = 4 \text{ m/s}$. If the mass is $2 \text{ kg}$, its kinetic energy is:
If an object's mass is doubled AND its speed is doubled, its kinetic energy increases by a factor of:
2 kg object at 3 m/s vs 4 kg at 2 m/s. Which has more kinetic energy?
questions.explanation: Object 1: $KE = \frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 9 = 9$ J. Object 2: $KE = \frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 4 = 8$ J. Object 1 has more.

questions.question: A 3 kg box slides down a 4 m inclined surface at an angle of $50^{\circ}$ to the horizontal. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the surface is $\mu_k = 0.2$. Find the net work done on the box. (Use $g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)
